P123-assisted synthesis of Co3O4 catalyst for efficiently catalyzing N2O decomposition under simulated real tail-gases Haibiao Yu Writing – review & editing Shanshan Qin Writing – original draft Xingkun Qi Data curation Keyi Wang Validation Yanan Li Visualization Yuanting Du Resources Xiaogeng Feng Formal analysis Weijun Shan Funding acquisition Ying Xiong Resources ⁎ College of Chemistry, Liaoning University, Shenyang 110036, PR China College of Chemistry Liaoning University Shenyang 110036 PR China College of Chemistry, Liaoning University, Shenyang 110036, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. The 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst was prepared by sol-gel method with the assistance of P123 and investigated for catalyzing N2O decomposition. Research indicated that although the specific surface area of 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst was only 18 m2·g−1, it exposed more highly active crystal planes, such as (111), (331), (400), and (222), and possessed higher surface oxygen vacancy density (5.64 µmol·m−2) compared with that of 0P-Co3O4 and Co3O4(P) catalysts. Due to these reasons, the corresponding reaction activation energy of 8.0P-Co3O4 for the reaction was significantly reduced, and the catalytic activity of 8.0P-Co3O4 was enhanced compared with that of Co3O4(P). Most importantly, the N2O conversion can maintain about 73 % over the catalyst for at least 24 h when the three impurity gases of 5 vol% O2, 100 ppmv NO, and 2 vol% H2O were coexisted at 400 °C, GHSV = 20,000 h−1. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords N2O decomposition Co3O4 P123 Catalyst microstructure Impurity gases Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitrous oxide (N2O) is the third most significant greenhouse gas, following carbon dioxide (CO2) and methane (CH4), due to its capacity to absorb infrared radiation or react with atmospheric ozone [1,2]. Over the past few decades, human industrial production and automobile exhaust emit a large amount of N2O [3]. Therefore, the elimination of N2O has attracted more and more attention. The standard methods for eliminating N2O include thermal decomposition, selective catalytic reduction, and direct catalytic decomposition methods [4–7]. Direct catalytic decomposition has become the most promising N2O elimination method because of its cheaper cost, simple operation, high efficiency, no need for reductant, and no secondary pollution [8]. The research of direct catalytic N2O decomposition mainly focuses on synthesizing catalysts with high catalytic performance in the real exhaust atmosphere environment [1]. Among all the studied catalysts, transition metal oxides, especially Co3O4, are highly significant and extensively researched in the catalytic decomposition of N2O due to their affordability, higher hydrothermal stability, unique high catalytic activity, and easy modification of their structure and physicochemical properties [9–11]. In the studies of improving the performance of cobalt-based catalysts for catalyzing N2O decomposition, various modification means have been chaired out [12]. The differences in preparation methods, or structural and morphological changes caused by adding additives, ultimately affect the catalytic performance of Co3O4 to a large extent. The primary preparation method of cobalt-based catalysts commonly used today is co-precipitation, which can obtain the catalyst with good activity by a simple method. Ohnishi et al. [12,13] found that during the preparation of Co3O4 catalysts by co-precipitation, different factors, such as precipitant, stirring temperature, and the duration of the precipitation, all significantly affected the catalytic decomposition of N2O over these catalysts by influencing the structure of Co3O4 precursor. Zamudio and his group [14] prepared MgCo2O4 spinel catalysts for N2O decomposition by solution combustion and co-precipitation methods, respectively. The results demonstrated that the catalysts obtained by co-precipitation method possessed optimal activity, which was related to the catalyst's larger specific surface area, higher surface activity, and more robust oxygen-enrichment capacity for weak chemisorption. Meanwhile, most researchers added additives to Co3O4 by co-precipitation to obtain a series of catalysts with excellent performance, such as Bi0.02Co [15], Pb0.04Co [16], Gd0.06Co [17] and Ag0.04Co [18]. In these catalysts, the improvement of catalyst activity not only depends on the electrical effect of the additive on the active component, but also relies on the structure modification effect by the additive, which is only possible to play its best role when prepared by co-precipitation [16]. However, as the research deepened, researchers gradually found that the traditional co-precipitation method and simple additive doping mode are challenging to boost the comprehensive properties of cobalt-based oxide catalysts, which cannot meet the harsh requirements of the catalyst for the actual treatment of N2O pollution in industrial waste gas. In previous studies, some researchers pointed out that the catalytic performance in the N2O decomposition of Co3O4 is significantly influenced and improved by unique microstructures or exposure to highly active crystalline surfaces [15,19]. Li et al. [19] used different preparation methods to produce nanocubbes, nanosheets, nanorods, and nanopolyhedral Co3O4. They found that nanocube-shaped Co3O4, mainly exposed to (001) crystalline surfaces, was more active than nanosheets and nanorods Co3O4 catalysts, exposed primarily to (110) crystalline surfaces. Back in 2016, Stelmakhovsky et al. [20] prepared Co3O4 catalysts with different shapes using different methods and found that the morphological structure of Co3O4 affects its surface electronic properties, which are closely related to its N2O decomposition performance. Sol-gel, a simple catalyst synthesis method, is often used to prepare N2O decomposition catalysts. Hu et al. produced a range of defective N-doped Co3O4 catalysts using a facile graphitic carbon nitride-modified sol-gel method [21]. The results of activity tests showed that catalytic activity was enhanced by nitrogen doping, which decreased activation energy and promoted surface Co2+ and primary sites. Liu et al. prepared a batch of Sm-doped Co3O4 catalysts for the efficient direct catalytic N2O decomposition using citric acid as the complexing agent and urea as the combusting agent by sol-gel method [17]. In addition, the research group integrated Co3O4 catalysts containing single atom Pr in their matrix using a sol-gel method, which showed improved catalytic efficiency and a volcanic-type change in reaction conversion with the amount of co-dose [22]. Furthermore, the surfactants were also used as the soft templates for catalyst preparation by sol-gel method [23,24]. Zhao et al. fabricated the mesoporous TiO2 film by sol-gel method with evaporation induced self-assembly process using F127 as templating agent in the mixed solution of ethanol and Tetra-n‑butyl Titanate [23]. Song et al. also used P123 as the soft template to prepare Ni- and Mn-promoted mesoporous Co3O4 [24]. However, in our previous study [25], it was found for the first time that the Co3O4 catalyst with particular “Yadan geomorphology” microstructure and exposed highly active (400) and (511) crystal planes can be successfully obtained based on sol-gel method, which is supplemented by the nonionic surfactant F127 (PEO106PPO70PEO106, Mav=12,600). The catalyst showed better low-temperature activity and stability than Co3O4 obtained by the conventional precipitation method when simulating the catalytic purification of N2O pollution from the tail gas of a nitric acid plant. It indicates that nonionic surfactants have great potential for synthesizing highly active catalysts using sol-gel method. In this study, the triblock copolymers P123 (PEO70PPO20PEO70, Mav=5800) with smaller molecular weights were selected to replace F127 to synthesize the xP-Co3O4 catalysts with more superior catalytic performance by sol-gel method. The work discusses the effect of the amount of added P123 on the unique morphology, crystal plane exposure, and catalytic performance. The catalytic activity and impurity gas stability of the optimal catalysts in an ideal environment and a simulated nitric acid plant exhaust gas were also evaluated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The cobalt nitrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O) was bought from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Company. Pluronic P123 (PEO70PPO20PEO70, Mav=5800) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Nitric acid (HNO3) and Sodium carbonate (Na2CO3) were bought from China Sinopharm International (Shanghai) Company. All reagents are analytically pure and used as is without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of xP-Co3O4 and Co3O4(P) catalysts The xP-Co3O4 catalysts are generally prepared via the sol-gel method, which is similar to the process previously described in our study [25]. First, a certain amount of P123 was added to 18 mL of dilute nitric acid solution (2 mol L−1), and 5 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O was added after stirring until complete dissolution. The mixed solution was stirred continuously at 90 ℃ to obtain a gel, which was then dried at 120 ℃ for more than 12 h. Finally, the catalyst sample was calcined under static air at 400 ℃ for 2 h. The catalyst was labeled as xP-Co3O4 based on the weight (grams) of P123 added to the mixed solution, where x represents 0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0, 6.0, 7.0, 7.5, 8.0, or 10.0 g. The schematic diagram of the preparation process for xP-Co3O4 catalysts was demonstrated in Fig. 1 . For comparison, the Co3O4(P) catalyst was also produced using the conventional precipitation method [17]. 2.3 Catalyst characterization This study obtained X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns using a Bruker D8 powder diffractometer under Cu Kα radiation. N2 adsorption analyses were performed on a Quanta Chromium ASIQ-C gas adsorption instrument with test samples degassed at 100 ℃ Celsius for 4 h. The morphology and microstructure of the catalyst samples were analyzed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, S-4800) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100). The material surface's elemental species and valence states were analyzed using a Thermo ESCALAB 250 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer. The O2-TPD was performed on Chem BET Pulsar TPR/TPD analyzer. All the above characterization methods and procedures were consistent with our previous reports [25]. 2.4 Activity tests and dynamic study The test process of catalyst activity evaluation is conducted at a fixed bed reactor (Fig. S1). The flue gas at a flow rate of 50 mL min−1 contained 2000 ppm N2O, 5 % O2 (when used), 100 ppm NO (when used), 2 % H2O (when used), and the carrier gas was Ar. The catalyst mass was 200 mg (40–60 mesh), and the corresponding GHSV was 20,000 h−1. The residual N2O concentration at the outlet was detected online through a six-way valve and a Varian CP-3800 gas chromatograph. The N2O conversion rate ratio is calculated using the following equation: (1) N 2 O conversion ( % ) = 1 − c [ N 2 O ] out c [ N 2 O ] in × 100 % where, c[N2O]in denotes the concentration of N2O at the inlet, while c[N2O]out denotes the concentration at the outlet, respectively. Moreover, it can be found that the N2O decomposition reaction over the xP-Co3O4 catalysts follows the law of first-order reaction kinetics by experimental measurements, which is in accordance with that reported in literature [16,26]. Hence, each kinetic parameter of the reaction over the specific catalyst (apparent reaction rate r ; reaction rate constant k ; transition frequency TOF ) was calculated by integrating the reaction results. The calculated equations were listed as follows [16]: (2) r = p 0 · F · 2000 × 1 0 − 6 R · T 0 · m cat × N 2 O Conv . % ( μ mol s − 1 g cat − 1 ) (3) k = r / c ¯ (4) T O F = r / n where, P 0 (Pa) stands for the atmospheric pressure, F (ml s−1) is the flow rate of feed gas, R (J K−1 mol−1) is gas constant, m cat (g) is the amount of used catalyst, T 0 (K) is the room temperature, c ¯ (μmol m−3) is the average N2O concentration calculated from those inlet and outlet of the reactor, n (μmol gcat −1) is the amount of active sites detected by O2-TPD (100 - 300 °C). It should be noted that the calculated TOF essentially represent the averaged catalytic activity for all types of sites. The E a was determined according to Arrhenius equation based on the reaction data in the temperature ranges 523–623 K for 8.0P-Co3O4 and 573–673 K for 0P-Co3O4 and Co3O4(P). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic properties of xP-Co3O4 for N2O decomposition Firstly, the catalytic performance of xP-Co3O4 catalysts (x = 0 - 10) for N2O decomposition was investigated, and the results were shown in Fig. 2 . As can be seen from the figure, the additional amount of P123 during the sol-gel preparation process significantly affected the catalytic activity of the prepared catalysts. When no P123 was added during the preparation process, the obtained 0P-Co3O4 catalyst showed inferior catalytic activity, and only 9.5 % N2O conversion can be obtained at 350 °C. However, when 2.0 g P123 was used, the N2O conversion sharply increased to 49 % at the same reaction conditions. It suggests that the P123 is an important participator for improving catalytic performance, regardless of the method used. The catalytic activity continues to increase with the increase of the amount of used P123 during the preparation process, and the maximum activity was reached when the amount of used P123 was 8.0 g, about 96.11 % N2O conversion to N2 and O2 at 350 °C. After reaching this value, the further increase in P123 amount does not lead to an improvement in catalyst performance. This changing trend of N2O conversion over xP-Co3O4 catalysts with the increase of P123 dosage during the preparation process was also exhibited in Fig. 3 . For economic benefits, 8.0 g P123 was determined as the optimal addition amount during preparation. Meanwhile, the Co3O4(P) catalyst, synthesized via a conventional precipitation method, was also tested for the N2O decomposition [27,28], as shown in Fig. 2. Obviously, the 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst has an absolute advantage in catalytic activity. Even when compared with the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst reported by our previous study [25], its advantage in catalytic activity is also apparent. This means that the highly active Co3O4 catalyst for catalyzing N2O decomposition can be obtained by sol-gel method using P123, which opens new avenues for the subsequent synthesis of highly active cobalt-based catalysts. 3.2 Textural structure characterization XRD was performed on the xP-Co3O4 catalysts (x = 0 - 10) to examine the influence of the added P123 during the preparation process on the crystalline phase of the obtained catalysts. As shown in Fig. 4 , the diffraction peaks of xP-Co3O4 catalysts were still consistent with the standard diffraction peaks of Co3O4 spinel (JCPDS 43–1003), and the crystalline phase did not change by the addition of P123 during the preparing process. The average crystallite sizes of Co3O4 in xP-Co3O4 catalysts were roughly calculated according to the Scherrer formula, as exhibited in the Table 1 . It can be found that the change in the crystal size of Co3O4 in the catalyst is not related to the amount of P123 added. Moreover, the N2 adsorption-desorption was also utilized to characterize the physical properties of 0P-Co3O4, 4.0P-Co3O4, 8.0P-Co3O4, and Co3O4(P) catalysts. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves were given in Fig. 5 . It can be observed that both catalysts show typical type IV isotherms with obvious hysteresis loops, which indicated the presence of mesoporous structure in both catalysts. The information of the specific surface area and pore structure parameters for the catalysts were also listed in the Table 1. It clearly shows that the specific surface area of the catalysts prepared by the sol-gel method is nearly unchanged with and without P123. The specific surface area of the 4.0P-Co3O4 and 8.0P-Co3O4 catalysts were only 15 and 18 m2·g−1, which were much lower than that of the Co3O4(P) (28 m2·g−1). Obviously, the pore volume of the 4.0P-Co3O4 and 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst were also smaller than that of the Co3O4(P). These results contradict the fact that the average crystallite sizes of Co3O4 in xP-Co3O4 catalysts were smaller than that in Co3O4(P) catalyst. It means that the microstructure of the catalyst crystallites is not spherical-like. Meanwhile, combined with the results obtained from Fig. 1, it can also be seen that the specific surface area is not a significant determinant of the performance of xP-Co3O4 catalysts. Fig. 6 demonstrates the SEM and EDS elemental surface-swept characterization images of the optimal 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst. It can be found that the catalyst has a lumpy morphology consisting of irregular secondary spherical particles (Fig. 6A, B). It is of greater significance that EDS elemental mapping (Fig. 6C, D) of Co and O elements on the 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst unequivocally demonstrates that both Co and O are distributed evenly in the catalyst. Except for Co and O, no other elements were found. In conjunction with the XRD characterization data, it proves that the used P123 surfactant has been completely removed during the calcination stage. To further explore the morphological changes of the catalyst, the microstructural morphology and crystal plane exposure of the 8.0P- Co3O4 catalyst were analyzed in more detail by TEM, and the photos were shown in Fig. 7 . Fig. 7A exhibited the TEM photos of the 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst at different positions at a magnification of 10,0000 times. The Co3O4 crystallite in the 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst exhibits an irregular morphology structure, presenting a variety of morphology structures, such as spheroidal, short rod, worm-like, and so on. It is important to note that Scherrer's formula cannot accurately calculate the average crystallite size for non-spherical catalyst crystals. Hence, the contradiction mentioned in the study of specific surface area no longer exists. Next, five different regions (① - ⑤) were selected from Fig. 7A and enlarged for further magnification, and the corresponding photos were shown in Fig. 7B-F. From the enlarged high magnification TEM photos, the 8.0P-Co3O4 catalysts mainly exposed (111), (331), (400), and (222) crystal planes, which is entirely different from the pure Co3O4 catalysts prepared via the conventional precipitation method (which mainly displayed (111) and (311)) [29]. That is, introducing P123 caused the Co3O4 catalyst to expose more different surface crystal planes. In addition, as can be seen in Fig. 7C, the region mainly exposes (222) crystal plane, with a very distinct truncated area (lower right side) in a large continuous sheet of particles. Meanwhile, the pore structure (r ≈ 4 nm) can also be identified in the diagram. This situation may be ascribed to the "etch-like" effect of P123 surfactant on Co3O4 grains during catalyst preparation. In the regions shown in Fig. 7D and E, layer-by-layer stacked structures appear (same crystal plane), as indicated by the yellow dashed lines in the two photos. The upper part of Fig. 7F is enlarged to obtain Fig. 7G, from which it is easy to find that there are many distorted lattice stripes in the blue-coated region, and most of these stripes are discontinuous, indicating the existence of many defects. These defect sites can be used as active sites for N2O decomposition, which may be the key to enhancing the catalytic performance. In conclusion, it may be speculated that when a certain quantity of P123 was added to the solution during preparation, the hydrophilic group of the block copolymer, polyethylene oxide (PEO), and the hydrophobic group, polypropylene oxide (PPO), self-assemble to form micelles, which influence the structure and morphology of prepared Co3O4 catalyst throughout the synthesis process. That is why the prepared xP-Co3O4 catalysts tended to expose more crystal planes and produce more defects during the catalyst synthesis. The preferential exposure of different crystalline surfaces and the formation of many surface defects may be essential reasons for the excellent catalytic performance of the catalyst. 3.3 Surface property The change in textural structure constantly alters the surface properties of the catalyst. Therefore, the surface properties of Co3O4(P), 0P-Co3O4, and 8.0P-Co3O4 catalysts were analyzed with the help of XPS. Fig. 8 illustrates the Co 2p spectra of the three catalysts. The two distinctive characteristic peaks at binding energies of ∼796.0 eV and ∼780.0 eV can be ascribed to the Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 orbitals of spinel-type Co3O4, respectively [30,31]. In comparison to Co3O4(P) and 0P-Co3O4 catalysts, the binding energy of the Co 2p3/2 spin orbitals for 8.0P-Co3O4 shift to the lower value (779.7 eV), which indicated that the Co-O bonds in the 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst were weakened with the auxiliary synthesis of P123 [18,32]. The Co 2p3/2 spectra were subjected to a more detailed peak splitting for the variance of Co species on the surface of the three catalysts to gain a deeper understanding. The peaks with electronic binding energies at ∼779.7 eV are attributed to Co3+, while those with binding energies at ∼781.2 eV are attributed to Co2+. After fitting the respective areas, it is easy to find that there is no significant increase in the percentage of Co3+ in the 0P-Co3O4 catalyst compared to Co3O4(P). However, after doping P123 during the preparation process, the rate of Co3+ increased from 47.9 % to 57.8 %, and the ratio of Co3+/Co2+ rose from 0.92 to 1.37. The increase in the percentage of Co3+ enriched the number of oxygen vacancies on the surface of the catalysts and enhanced the reactivity of the catalytic decomposition of N2O [33]. In addition, the O 1s orbitals of the three catalysts also peaked as shown in Fig. 8B. The O 1s orbital spectra of Co3O4(P) contained three binding energies of 530.0 eV, 531.2 eV, and 532.6 eV, which were attributed to the surface lattice oxygen (Oβ), the surface adsorbed oxygen (Oα1), and the oxygen coming from the water or the surface of the catalyst (Oα2), respectively [34,35]. The different surface oxygen atomic occupancies were obtained by calculating the respective areas. As shown in Fig. 8B, the proportions of Oα1, Oα2, and Oβ of Co3O4(P) catalyst was 10.9 %, 41.9 %, and 47.2 %, respectively. For the 0P-Co3O4 catalysts, the proportions of Oα1, Oα2, and Oβ wre 13.0, 46.7, and 40.3. However, for the 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst, it has the largest surface adsorbed oxygen content among the three catalysts, which was as high as 50.1 %. The doping of P123 leads to an increase in adsorbed oxygens on the catalyst's surface, which is the same as the conclusion that the 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst contains more Co3+. In addition, the overall trend of 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst showed a shift towards lower binding energy, which is also presumed to be because of the addition of P123 during the synthesis process. It is generally accepted that surface oxygen vacancies were employed as the active sites for the N2O decomposition reaction [15,16,19,36–38]. However, the surface adsorbed oxygen (Oα1) detected by XPS can only qualitatively characterize the number of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface. Hence, the O2-TPD behaviors of the three catalysts were recorded to explore the Co-O bond strength and quantitatively characterize the number of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst's surface, and the results were shown in Fig. 9 . It can be found that the initial desorption temperature of oxygen was 134, 142 and 158 °C for 8.0P-Co3O4, 0P-Co3O4 and Co3O4(P) catalysts, respectively. It means that the Co-O bond on the surface of 8.0P-Co3O4 is the weakest. The result also follows that obtained from XPS. Subsequently, the deoxygenation amounts of the three catalysts were obtained by calculating the peak areas of Co3O4(P), 0P-Co3O4, and 8.0P-Co3O4 converted in the range of 100 - 300 °C, which were 11.64, 26.38 and 50.77 μmol g−1, respectively. Since one oxygen molecule can occupy two oxygen vacancies, the number of oxygen vacancies on the surface of these three catalysts are 23.28, 52.76, and 101.54 μmol g−1. Adding P123 enhances the number of active sites of this catalyst to 4.36 times compared to Co3O4(P). The surface oxygen vacancy density of the 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst in the range of 100 - 300 °C was 5.64 µmol m −2, about 7 times higher than that of the Co3O4(P) catalyst. It is important to note that although the 0P-Co3O4 catalyst contains weaker Co-O bonds and a higher number of surface oxygen vacancies compared with Co3O4(P) catalyst, its catalytic activity is the worst. This is attributed to the fact that 0P-Co3O4 exposed more inactive (422) crystalline plane, which had already been raised by our previous study [25]. 3.4 Reaction kinetics study It is widely known that the decomposition of N2O over the catalyst follows the law of first-order reaction [16,26]. To analyze the constitutive relationships of the catalysts in several dimensions, the kinetic parameters of 8.0P-Co3O4 were calculated and compared with those of Co3O4(P) and 0P-Co3O4 (0F-Co3O4) catalysts [25]. The specific reaction rates (r) and reaction rate constants (k) for N2O decomposition reaction at different temperatures over the three catalysts were listed in the Table 2 . At 300 °C, the specific reaction rate r of Co3O4(P) is 0.027 μmol g−1, while that of 8.0P-Co3O4 is 0.422 μmol g−1, which is 15.6 times higher than that of the former. Meanwhile, the number of active sites of the 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst is 4.4 times higher than that of Co3O4(P), which means that at least 3.5 times of the 15.6-fold increase in the catalytic N2O decomposition is attributed to the weakening of the Co-O bond due to the alteration of the microstructure (exposure of high active crystal planes) of Co3O4 by the incorporation of P123. The TOF value also proves for the above point, which is about 3.6 times higher (4.16 × 10−3 s−1) for 8.0P-Co3O4 compared to Co3O4(P) (1.16 × 10−3 s−1). The activation energies of the three catalysts for catalyzing decomposition of the N2O reaction were computed according to the Arrhenius equation (Fig. 10 ), and the Ea value of 8.0P-Co3O4 was 55.0 kJ mol−1, which was significantly lower than the other two catalysts (78.6 kJ mol−1 for Co3O4(P) and 82.1 kJ mol−1 for 0P-Co3O4). 3.5 Catalytic performance test One criterion for determining whether the catalyst can be used in actual industrial plant production is whether the catalyst has good resistance to impurity gases under actual gas conditions. Since N2O often coexists with NO, O2, and H2O in the tail gas of a nitric acid plant [1,6], a series of investigations on the impurity gas resistance of the 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst were carried out in this subsection. Fig. 11A and 11B showed the conversion of catalytic decomposition of N2O over 8.0P-Co3O4 and Co3O4(P) catalysts in 2000 ppmv N2O/Ar feed gas coexisting with 100 ppmv NO, 5 vol.% O2 or 2 vol.% H2O, respectively. For the 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst, under ideal conditions (only 2000 ppmv N2O/Ar, 50 mL·min−1), the temperature when N2O conversation achieves 50 % (T 50) was 271 °C. When 5 vol.% O2, 100 ppmv NO, and 2 vol.% H2O were introduced, the T 50 increased to 314, 333, and 305 °C, an increase of 43, 62, and 34 °C, respectively. When a mixture of gases such as 5 vol.% O2 + 100 ppmv NO or 5 vol.% O2 + 100 ppmv NO + 2 vol.% H2O was introduced into the feed gas, the T 50 of the 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst increased to 350 and 377 °C, with an increase of 79 and 106 °C, respectively. For the Co3O4(P) catalyst, although the increment of T 50 during the different impurity gases introduced into the reaction system was lower than that for 8.0P-Co3O4, when all three impurity gases were introduced, the catalyst had a T 50 as high as 424 °C, as shown in Fig. 11B. The stability of the 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst was tested by examining the change in N2O conversion with flow time under specified reaction conditions. Fig. 12 shows the catalytic stability of the 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst demonstrated by passing or removing various impurity gases at 400 °C. As shown in the figure, when 5 vol.% O2 was continuously passed for 4 h, its activity for catalytic decomposition of N2O did not decrease and remained at 100 %. When 100 ppmv NO gas was continued to be fed, the activity dropped to ∼ 85 % and remained constant. Subsequently, 2 vol.% H2O was passed, at which time the N2O conversion over the catalyst dropped to ∼ 73 %. After 24 h of continuous operation, the catalytic activity remained at a stable value without decreasing. The N2O conversion of the catalyst was restored to 100 % after the three impurity gases were sequentially removed. It was proved that the impurity gases did not cause irreversible poisoning to the catalyst, and the effects of the impurity gases O2, H2O, and NO on the catalytic performance of the catalyst were reversible. In addition, the stabilized catalytic activity of 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst was also compared with that reported in the literature, and the results were listed in Table S1 [17,18,22,25,37,39–43]. Although no additives were added, 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst can still exhibit higher stable catalytic activity under the presence of O2, H2O, and NO. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of xP-Co3O4 catalysts for catalyzing N2O decomposition were prepared by sol-gel method with the auxiliary of nonionic surfactant P123. The amount of P123 used during the sol-gel preparation process significantly affects the catalytic activity of the prepared catalysts. When the amount of P123 used was 8.0 g, about 96.11 % N2O conversion to N2 and O2 at 350 °C, which was much higher than that of Co3O4(P) catalyst. The characterization of the textural structure showed that adding P123 made the catalyst display a variety of morphology structures, such as spheroidal, short rod, worm-like, and so on. Although 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst has a low specific surface area (only 18 m2·g−1), it exposed many highly active crystal planes, such as (111), (331), (400), and (222). Surface property analysis indicated that the number of active sites on the 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst was also significantly enhanced, and the surface oxygen vacancy density of the catalyst in the temperature range of 100 - 300 °C was 5.64 µmol·m−2, about 7 times higher than that of the Co3O4(P) catalyst. In addition, N2O conversion of ∼73 % was maintained over 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst at 400 °C for more than 24 h with all three impurity gases passed in, resulting in excellent catalytic stability. coredata.dc:description: The 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst was prepared by sol-gel method with the assistance of P123 and investigated for catalyzing N2O decomposition. Research indicated that although the specific surface area of 8.0P-Co3O4 catalyst was only 18 m2·g−1, it exposed more highly active crystal planes, such as (111), (331), (400), and (222), and possessed higher surface oxygen vacancy density (5.64 µmol·m−2) compared with that of 0P-Co3O4 and Co3O4(P) catalysts. Due to these reasons, the corresponding reaction activation energy of 8.0P-Co3O4 for the reaction was significantly reduced, and the catalytic activity of 8.0P-Co3O4 was enhanced compared with that of Co3O4(P). Most importantly, the N2O conversion can maintain about 73 % over the catalyst for at least 24 h when the three impurity gases of 5 vol% O2, 100 ppmv NO, and 2 vol% H2O were coexisted at 400 °C, GHSV = 20,000 h−1.
